This hook will only be called if partitioning is enabled in the JPA + * server. + *

+ * Hooks may accept the following parameters: + *

+ *
    + *
  • + * org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IBaseResource - The resource that will be created and needs a tenant ID assigned. + *
    • + *
  • + * ca.uhn.fhir.rest.api.server.RequestDetails - A bean containing details about the request that is about to be processed, including details such as the + * resource type and logical ID (if any) and other FHIR-specific aspects of the request which have been + * pulled out of the servlet request. Note that the bean + * properties are not all guaranteed to be populated, depending on how early during processing the + * exception occurred. + *
    • + *
  • + * ca.uhn.fhir.rest.server.servlet.ServletRequestDetails - A bean containing details about the request that is about to be processed, including details such as the + * resource type and logical ID (if any) and other FHIR-specific aspects of the request which have been + * pulled out of the servlet request. This parameter is identical to the RequestDetails parameter above but will + * only be populated when operating in a RestfulServer implementation. It is provided as a convenience. + *
    • + *
+ *

+ * Hooks should return an instance of ca.uhn.fhir.jpa.api.model.PartitionId or null. + *

+ */ + STORAGE_PARTITION_IDENTIFY_CREATE( + // Return type + "ca.uhn.fhir.interceptor.model.PartitionId", + // Params + "org.hl7.fhir.instance.model.api.IBaseResource", + "ca.uhn.fhir.rest.api.server.RequestDetails", + "ca.uhn.fhir.rest.server.servlet.ServletRequestDetails" + ), + + /** + * Storage Hook: + * Invoked before FHIR read/access operation (e.g. read/vread, search, history, etc.) operation to request the + * identification of the partition ID to be associated with the resource being created. replies.bodyText: Changed to RequestPartitionId
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Is this the first time we're requesting a non-boolean from a callback?  I wonder if we need to consider any other concerns--e.g. any consequences for other languages we need to consider?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: No, we've done this before.. E.g. for delete conflicts
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: right!

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick: That's a lot of parameters.  Looks like an opportunity to group them together into a new class.
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: It's kinda gross, but this approach helps us have one codebase to validate all versions.. i actually put it this way to fix a bug where the checks were inconsistent across versions

timeline.bodyText: I suspect there may need to be changes to LiveBundle
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: I'm adjusting it to just not support partitioning for now...
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.author: fil512

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick: this looks like a method
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: refactored
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I wonder what the performance implications of this will be.  Good idea putting it first.
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: This will absolutely require index tuning in order to work in a performant way...
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: This surprises me.  I guess this is a fairly urgent TODO to add support for history back in when partitioning is enabled?  This means that FMC will lose the history operation?  I don't think this came across in the docs that we are switching off functionality like this when partitions are switched on.
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Yeah, I'll make that the next ticket
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: This is an interesting tradeoff of read/write performance.  I think you chose the better option.  I guess another option would be to index partition id with pid and do the find directly on that.  But I guess that doesn't work with partition id = null as an option.  (Maybe a reason to consider default partition = 0?).
timeline.author: fil512

timeline.bodyText: I don't think line changes the behaviour.  Did you add it for future change safety?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: yup
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I see these in all the predicates.  It feels dangerous to expect all the predicates to explicitly set this properly.  (Or maybe it's just an optimization thing).  Isn't there an inexpensive way to test if the query root has joins at the point where we need to know?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: it's just an optimization thing... the consequence of missing it is that an  extra predicate on the resource type + partition ends up in the SQL... that only hurts performance
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: This cache timeout seems really short to me--I assume this table changes really infrequently.  Can we just invalidate the cache whenever the table is changed and set the refresh to way longer?
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: That's dangerous in a cluster..
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I know there are "reasons" but man why can't we just make this a CRUD REST service?  Would probably be like 5 lines of Spring code...
timeline.author: fil512

timeline.bodyText: This is a great regression test for tracking how code changes affect db interactions.  It's the gift that keeps on giving.

replies.bodyText: Yeah I love this test!
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: the test would be clearer if it calculated this number instead of hardcoding it.

replies.bodyText: this way is safest in terms of catching accidental changes to the algorithm though

replies.bodyText: we add 2 creates because we're about to create 2 resources... i'lll reorder to make that more clear

timeline.bodyText:
this is unlikely to fail, but this feels like a weak assert.
Can you strength any() here?  can it go createPartition(eq(expectedPartition))
timeline.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: We're verifying the response, which contains the same contents we sent in, so we know it is good.
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText:
but the service is mocked
I think the ideal mock provider tests confirm that the REST parameters got properly translated to service method parameters
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Well yeah but that mock implementation returns the same thing it receives, not a hardcoded response. So if we see data in the response, it can only have come from the request. I'm not getting what added value testing things in the intermediate state would add, unless we didn't trust HAPI's operations framework
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: That means the test assumes that the provider returns what the service returns unchanged.  Might be a safe assumption or it might not be.  I'd need to look at the implementation to know.
replies.author: fil512
